conclusion: Understand the behavior of the charged particle in the electric field before and after the metal plate is removed.
The parallel-plate capacitor has a constant voltage V across its plates.
The distance between the plates is d.
A metal plate with thickness l is placed on the lower plate.
The charged particle P is stationary above the metal plate, indicating that the net force on it is zero.
The electric field E between the plates of a capacitor is given by E = V/d.
When the metal plate is inserted, it affects the distribution of the electric field, but the field above the metal plate balances the gravitational force on the particle.
The gravitational force on the particle is F_g = mg.
The electric force on the particle is F_e = qE.
Since the particle is stationary, F_e = F_g, thus qE = mg.
When the metal plate is removed, the electric field returns to its original uniform distribution E = V/d.
The electric force on the particle becomes F_e' = qV/d.
The net force on the particle after removing the metal plate is F_net = qV/d - mg.
Using Newton's second law, the acceleration a of the particle is a = (qV/md) - g.
The acceleration of the particle's motion after the metal plate is removed is a = (qV/md) - g.
